docs.lead_paragraph: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did. From all over Long Island, letters poured in. Stories of friends made in kindergarten and in college, at work and at the beach. Tales of friendships forged through marriage: husbands and wives, mothers-in-law and sons-in-law. Stories of friendships that have lasted whole lifetimes, whether the writer was 9 years old or 90.

headline.main: Friends, Indeed: Stories From the Heart; One Safe Prediction: Friday Nights Are Forever

docs.abstract: Cindy Schwartz letter, responding to query about best friends, describes her relationship with Heidi Heffron; photo (Special Issue: Best of Long Island) (M)
docs.snippet: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.    From all over Long Island,  letters poured in. Stories of friends made in kindergarten and in college, at work and at the beach. Tales of friendships forged through marriage: husbands and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Never give up. That's the message of five Long Islanders who, despite the odds, turned their lives around and realized their wildest dreams. From a museum president once labeled as lazy and stupid, a successful businesswoman beaten down by an abusive spouse, a college professor who was once a welfare mother and a young woman saddled by unfortunate family circumstances, they prove that obstacles can be overcome at any point in life. Not only have the people we have chosen to spotlight conquered stumbling blocks, met challenges and realized their own self-worth, after changing their lives they have also become role models, inspiring others and making a difference.

headline.main: The Small but Sure Steps Taken To Turn Their Lives Around

docs.abstract: Profiles of teacher Deborah McGrath, sociologist Barbara Peters, mortgage company management trainee Tamika Stewart, ecologist and dinosaur enthusiast Steve Gittelman and catering hall owner Rhonda Silver, all of Long Island, who, despite strong odds against them, turned their lives around and became successful; photos (Special Issue: Best of Long Island) (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In what might be a record for such a case, a woman has given birth to a healthy baby nearly five months after his twin died in a premature birth, a spokesman at Good Samaritan Hospital, where the birth occurred, said today. The woman, Debbie Feitl, spent 152 days in arrested labor before giving birth to a boy, Jared, four weeks ago, said Jeff Blunt, the spokesman.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Boy Is Born 5 Months After His Twin Died

docs.abstract: Debbie Feitl, in what might be record for such case, gives birth to healthy baby in Cincinnati nearly five months after his twin died in premature birth (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: CALL L. L. Bean, the clothing and outdoor gear company, don't identify yourself in any way, place your order, and see what happens. If you have shopped there before and you're calling from your home telephone number, the folks there know it -- even if you've blocked Caller ID. They know where you live. And they have your credit card number. In the course of the transaction, the cheerful sales clerk on the other end of the line will happily recite that information to you, letting you dispense with the tedium of giving your full credit card number or spelling your street name.

headline.main: Do You Know Who's Watching You? Do You Care?

docs.abstract: Privacy issues are raised by changes in technology that have made what used to be private information available to any company that will pay for it; thousands of computers linked to Web track individual patterns of online buying and behavior, which are translated in turn into highly sophisticated marketing strategies; most Americans are willing to part with personal information as long as they get something in return, and know what is to be done with information; but they are highly protective of their medical records and are generally appalled when they learn of clandestine data collection practices; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This is the season when doctors who perform abortions consider going on vacation. ''During this time of year, do not walk or jog in your neighborhood or anywhere else on a regular schedule,'' warned a police bulletin distributed last week by the Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists of Canada to its members. ''Consider wearing body armor, including at home. Do not put on or take off your body armor in public, including parking lots and public bathrooms.''

headline.main: Security Fears Rise at Clinics For Abortions In Canada

docs.abstract: Canadian doctors who perform abortions are exercising caution as November 11 Remembrance Day holiday approaches; in last five years, five Canadian and American doctors have been shot on or around November 11, which antiabortion militants on both sides of border call Remember the Unborn Children Day (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The thalidomide tragedy of the 1960's touched off intense concern and a vast amount of research about the safety of drugs taken during pregnancy. Many drugs (and druglike substances, including coffee, alcohol and tobacco) were tested in laboratory animals or studied in pregnant women. Some were found to be potential hazards to developing fetuses, usually only at the beginning of pregnancy but in some cases only near the time of birth and in others throughout gestation. Now most pregnant women are cautioned to avoid any and all medications that are not absolutely essential, as well as ''pleasure drugs'' like alcohol and tobacco and sometimes coffee and caffeine. But while this is sound advice in general, it can often result in needless discomfort for women who avoid taking a harmless drug that could help them. It also causes undue anxiety among those women who must take medication or who inadvertently took one or more drugs before they knew they were pregnant.

headline.main: Drugs, Safe and Not Safe, in Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on drugs that pregnant women can safely take and drugs they should avoid; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has some strong ideas about promoting morality in the school systems, but some of his methods seem faulty (news article, Nov. 3). Having children take pledges of virtue seems useless in the fight against teenage pregnancy.
